It's important that you be able to tolerate eachother's hobbies and interests at the minimum. The other extreme can be a problem too though, I dated this one girl, big sci-fi nerd, we'd spend hours talking about Stargate and Farscape and Babylon 5 etc. Then there was one of the shows, can't even remember which, but we had the most minor disagreement about something and she acted like it was the end of the world. "I thought we liked all the same things... I don't even know you! I swallowed a stranger's cum!" Actual quote. The sweetspot is when you both like your own things, but then you find something you can both enjoy. Game of Thrones as the go to show for this for a while, until it wasn't.

If she doesn't tolerate your taste at all though, this is an actual argument I had with an ex:

>I'm so sick of all your nerd shit! You have an entire wall in this apartment that's nothing but video games! Grow the fuck up!
Are you serious right now? I'm pretty sure the fifty or so plush animals now dominating the space on my bed are yours. You're really going to give me shit about a hobby where the average consumer is 35 when you had me take you to fucking Build-A-Bear last week?
>That's different! You know I'm a little, how am I supposed to picture you as a daddy if you act like a manchild?
I didn't sign on for that shit, I told you I'll read you stories but I will not pretend you're four years old. And last I checked I'm paying for everything in this apartment.
>Well one day you're going to come home and all your stupid video games are going to be gone.
You throw out my shit, I throw you out.
>OH MY GOD YOU'RE THREATENING ME NOW?! Y-YOU'RE GOING TO ATTACK ME?!
No, you know that's not- oh knock it off! I mean I'd take all of your shit, toss it on the porch and call the cops. You didn't want your name on the lease, remember? You can go back to living with your actual daddy.

He defeats the guy who destroyed his home planet in the first half of Z, but travels to the home planet of one of the redeemed baddies from a previous saga to do so. The show is also about family, Goku is not the only survivor of his home planet, and both him and the other guy have children of their own passing on their genes.

He DID choose having a son over his wife's well-being though. Aemma's pregnancies were all difficult ones, physically and/or psychologically. They should have stopped trying sooner, but Viserys wanted a son, so they kept trying. She would've likely died even without the c-section, so the damage had been done already. It wasn't because he was a sexist though, at least not anymore than anyone else in the setting is. He clearly loved Aemma and regretted pushing her to keep having children even after failing many times, and most of all he regretted that her dying moments were spent in agony begging him not to have the maester cut her open, because of his decision.

Neytiri is grappling with very well justified feelings of grief and anger towards humans in general. She doesn't feel this way about "My Jake", because she regards him as a true Na'vi. What Avatar 3 is going to delve into is the fact some Na'vi (the Ash People) are evil (an idea that has never occured to Neytiri), and that some humans are good. Not just tolerable in the way Spider is tolerable, but good. She and Jake don't realise this, but back on Earth some humans are horrified by what is going on on Pandora, much like how people in Spain and such were horrified when they discovered what Columbus was doing, and RDA is only being allow to get away with the shit they're getting away with due to the desperate situation on Earth. Humans who have never met Neytiri are going to lay their lives down for the Na'vi, even if it means they die on a polluted and corrupted Earth, and it's going to shake Neytiri to her core.

>In late 1992, Akira Kurosawa hosted a party for the cast and crew of Madadayo following the completion of principal photography. Honda appeared to be suffering from cold symptoms at the party and contacted his son Ryuji in New York. Ryuji believed Honda was drunk and thought it strange that he called him.[99] Then, in mid-February 1993, Kurosawa, Honda, and Masahiko Kumada, the unit manager, attended a screening of The Stranger, Indian filmmaker Satyajit Ray's last film, at an art-house cinema.[99] After watching the film, Kurosawa invited Honda to his house for dinner and drinks, but Honda felt sick and went home. Honda was declared healthy following a checkup in December 1992, and no major illnesses were suspected. Although his cough kept getting worse, his family doctor diagnosed him with a common cold.[100] Initially, Honda stayed in bed for a week, but after he lost his appetite, he underwent X-rays and blood tests. Honda was immediately told to seek hospital treatment following the results. Knowing something was wrong with his health, Honda had already packed his bags. Within ten minutes of leaving home, he was taken to Kono Medical Clinic, a 19-bed facility in Soshigaya. Because the major hospitals were full, he was placed in a tiny room.[100]

I can tell you two reasons for it's poor showing in Japan.
First, people are still working. Businesses and schools are still open. Schools are closing later this week and next week is when businesses start winding down. Normies are waiting for the New Year period to go to the movie theater.
Second, it hasn't been that well promoted here. When the first came out there was a ton more hype. This is a problem because Japanese pop culture moves so fast. There a ton of "here today, gone tomorrow" properties. Lots of TV shows and movies are big hits but disappear quickly from the public consciousness. It's a strategic failure.

Firstable, I work at one of the best secondary schools in Japan. The workload is really not much worse than in American schools. Half of the students barely even care about grades because colleges don’t look at them and only entrance exams matter. Secondable, there are only like 8 secondary schools in all of Tokyo. The vast majority go to junior and then senior high school after elementary school.

>>178119471
>>178119590
Further cope. Your freedom as an ALT entirely depends on the Japanese teacher, and more often than not if you suck ass at teaching they recognize it and relegate you to the role of a human pronunciation machine. At my school I teach grammar points in English, help students one-on-one with speech competitions and college prep, conduct full lessons on western culture, and lead speaking activities. I’ve also been invited by the Tokyo Board of Education to interview new Japanese teachers of English, facilitate group discussions following guest lectures, and help conduct entrance exams for international students. Why? Because I’m good at English and good at explaining shit in terms ESL learners can understand. Meanwhile there’s another JET at my school who’s gradually gotten her freedom taken away from her because she doesn’t know much about proper grammar, teaches about shitty pop culture like Star Wars and Marvel, and makes students uncomfortable. Even then, she’s a good resource for the teachers and helps students by letting them hear native speakers talking in English.
As regards the textbooks, I only see unnatural speech or outdated/arbitrary grammar rules very rarely. 99% of the time the textbooks are correct, and the Japanese teachers explain the grammar points correctly. There are some overly simplistic constructions and vocabulary that they learn early on that make them sound a bit juvenile, but that’s the case with any language taught as a second language. By their last year they’re on average far better at English than most Americans students are at the second languages they learn in high school. And if they make mistakes, that’s their own fault because they have been taught the language correctly.

Not very. It's about family issues. The dynamics of adopted children, a father's ability to acknowledge his son as a man. An unresolved arc about Sigourney Weaver's daughter having magic nature controlling powers. There are no gays of any kind, the scientists are a bunch of limp-wrists that get pushed around by military chads, and I don't think there's a single black person in the entire movie.

That said, the aboriginal native aliens are based on a lot of non-white tribal cultures and they do slaughter a lot of humans, though not all of them are white. There's a not so subtle screed against whaling. Environmentalism is a big part of it, of course, though they never really specifically bring up anything (they never say climate change, for example).

Movie becomes a highschool fitting in story (New York family moves to California and the kids get bullied while learning to fit-in and surf)
He these whales are super smart a cool, basically another sentient species
Oh No Quaritch has found where Jake's family live and now the last hour of the film is all of James Cameron's best action sequences (Aliens, Titanic, Terminator 2) blended together

We are searching for an ideal image of our own world: we go in quest of a planet, a civilization superior to our own but developed on the basis of a prototype of our primeval past. At the same time, there is something inside us which we don't like to face up to, from which we try to protect ourselves, but which nevertheless remains, since we don't leave Earth in a state of primal innocence. Yes… it’s not about profit. A material that has, on its own, extreme practical value cannot be belittled to mere “profit.” Profit in your Marxist sense is excess capital. That is not what Pandora brings to humans. It brings life. Literally it extends the life of individual humans and creates an economic structure designed to promote and prolong the lives of as many humans as possible. When a object of practical value is extracted through market forces, and profit is generated, that is nothing more than the most efficient and effective vehicle for extracting the product to engage in its practical benefits at maximum capacity. That is like saying we only drill for oil for “profit.” No; we drill for oil so that humans don’t starve and freeze to death in the winter. And so that we have enough resources to engage in a global economy, which is the only reason poverty is being eradicated as we speak. We are on track for there to be no impoverished nations on earth in a mere decade. That is not “profit.” It is growth. You can call it greed. But you need to take off your Marxist glasses to perceive reality correctly.

>>178121545
The show, at least in its first season or two, basically should just have been episodically focused around Geralt killing monsters and maybe occasionally getting roped into things (such as disputes, political intrigue etc.) he wants to avoid. Instead the show has a huge focus on Yennefer (thus taking away the focus from Geralt doing Witcher contracts), plus you also have the issue of S1 being unchronological. The show would have been better served by introducing Yennefer (without such a heavy focus on her backstory and in general) and Ciri in S2. By S3 the show could have moved away from the episodic format towards to more season-long stories (including the focus around Ciri). You have other issues - namely casting and costume design - though fundamentally the writing is the biggest problem; many people would be more accepting/forgiving of the other problems if there was better writing. Altogether you just get the impression, from what we see in the show and what we hear from bts, that the showrunners have either no understand and/or respect for neither the source material and fans. Notable things that stick out to me are the death of Eskel and how they wanted to handle the death of Roach.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>178119109

Low contrast, flat lighting, high degree of color grading.

These things were/are implemented to facilitate easier post-production and have become a style in their own right.

People used to care about lighting and tone more because you had to color match shots in editing and shooting on film meant you can only do so many takes etc... With digital it is implied things are going to get "sorted out" in post, so the pressure to get the perfect shot is less relevant since you can have like ...4 digital cameras shooting at the same time with slightly different angles and you can tweak the tone of all of it later on. PIck and choose, mix and match, reshoot with the same flat lighting on a green screen set ... who gives a shit. Some "color grading" monkey expert will tint it all blue in the end.
